description:
Cercospora kikuchii is a fungal plant pathogen that primarily infects soybean (Glycine max) plants. It is the causal agent of Cercospora leaf blight, a common foliar disease in soybean-growing regions.

The fungus belongs to the genus Cercospora, which is a group of ascomycete fungi known for their ability to cause various leaf spot and blight diseases in a wide range of host plants. Cercospora kikuchii specifically targets the leaves, stems, and pods of soybean plants, leading to the development of characteristic symptoms such as reddish-purple lesions on the leaves and pods.

The fungus reproduces through the production of conidia, which are asexual spores that can be dispersed by wind, rain, or other means. These conidia land on the soybean plant and germinate, penetrating the host tissue and establishing an infection. The disease can lead to premature defoliation, reduced pod formation, and decreased seed quality, ultimately resulting in significant yield losses for soybean growers.

Effective management of Cercospora leaf blight involves a combination of cultural practices, such as crop rotation and the use of resistant soybean cultivars, as well as the application of fungicides when necessary to control the disease and minimize its impact on soybean production.
